text: This is a really obscure game that I really like the ending of this game (one of my favorites) although the gameplay was very average and kinda grindy. I wish they made the gameplay more interactive, then it would have very fun game.

text: cool
author: Derrick .T

text: I absolutely LOVED the premise, the story, and the ending (one of my favorite endings of all time), but I wasn't a huge fan of the gameplay. I didn't care for the battle system, or any of the characters outside the main plot. If a little more thought went into the gameplay, this game would be amazing. So close, yet so far...

text: i hated the whole point and click battle system. MMO's killed that for me.

@Theramdomguy674 Atlus published it. The game was developed by Grasshopper Manufacture.

author: Rocco Koolaid

text:
@MrInnocentNixon Fighting is sort of awkward. You switch between a 'passive' and 'combat' mode. You can't attack in passive but you move faster and in combat you become slower but can attack. I haven't played in a while but I think the player attacks are automated so you pretty much need to time them instead of button mash.

Not horrible, but different. I can't really compare it to anything else, to be frank.

author: Wiizpig

text:
For anyone who has the Contact OST: compare "Run Cat 1" with "Run, My Dog, Run" from the Mother 3 OST. Then compare the scenes they're from.

Then consider they were released a month apart—and the games' graphical styles.

It's crazy! I love both games to death, FYI.

text: It's a good game, but it could have been SO much better !
author: Gontrand00

text:
From the same team, Grasshopper. Suda 51 was just the producer on this one, though he contributed some ideas to the production. The guy who directed the game was actually the graphics designer for Mario RPG.

It's definitely different from k7 and NMH, but it's still full of cool, offbeat ideas.
